Introduction

Liver abscesses are the most common type of intraabdominal abscess.  In resource-limited settings, they have a relatively high incidence and are usually caused by parasitic infections (eg, Entamoeba histolytica, Echinococcus).  In contrast, in resource-abundant settings, liver abscesses are uncommon and are most often caused by bacterial infection; these pyogenic liver abscesses are the focus of this article.

Pathophysiology and microbiology



Pyogenic liver abscess can result from direct spread from the biliary tract or surrounding structures, or hematogenous spread through the portal vein or systemic circulation.  Most abscesses are polymicrobial, with enteric gram-negative bacilli, streptococci (eg, Streptococcus milleri, typically associated with infection at other sites), and certain gram-positive organisms (eg, Staphylococcus aureus) being the most common pathogens.  In East Asia (eg, Thailand), Klebsiella pneumoniae is a prominent cause.



More specifically, routes through which bacteria can gain access to the liver include:



  • Biliary tract infection (eg, ascending cholangitis), which is usually caused by enteric gram-negative bacilli (eg, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella) and enterococci
  • Portal vein infection (eg, pyemia), which develops particularly in the setting cases of infections of the gastrointestinal tract (eg, diverticulitis, appendicitis)
  • Direct invasion from an adjacent source (eg, peritonitis, cholecystitis)
  • Hepatic artery (systemic hematogenous seeding)
  • Penetrating trauma or injury (eg, stab wound), which typically results in abscesses that contain mixed aerobic and anaerobic flora


Once bacteria reach the liver, various immune cells (eg, neutrophils, macrophages, lymphocytes) release inflammatory mediators (eg, cytokines) that can damage liver tissue and promote abscess formation.  Pyogenic liver abscesses are typically (but not always) single and can vary in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters.  The abscess cavity is filled with pus, which may contain bacteria, neutrophils, and tissue debris.  The right lobe of the liver is more commonly involved due to its more substantial size and blood supply.

Risk factors



  • Diabetes mellitus can impair immune function and increase the risk of infections, including liver abscesses.
  • Immunosuppression (HIV infection, chemotherapy, liver transplant)
  • Hepatobiliary or pancreatic disease
  • Foreign bodies, especially intraabdominal foreign bodies such as biliary stents or surgical drains, can provide a nidus for infection and abscess formation.

Clinical presentation



Pyogenic liver abscesses usually present with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and hepatomegaly.  Patients can also have systemic manifestations (eg, malaise, nausea/vomiting, weight loss).



Leukocytosis and elevated liver enzymes are common, typically with greater increases in alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin (eg, jaundice) than in aminotransferases.  Elevated inflammatory markers and normochromic, normocytic anemia (of chronic disease) may be present but are nonspecific.



When located in the hepatic dome, a liver abscess can cause diaphragmatic irritation and a sterile right-sided pleural effusion; occasionally the abscess may rupture, spread through the diaphragm, seed the pleural space, and create an empyema.

Diagnosis



Liver abscesses are diagnosed with abdominal imaging, which can be performed rapidly and noninvasively.



  • Ultrasonography:  Often the initial imaging study, an ultrasound can reveal a well-defined, hypoechoic or hyperechoic, fluid-filled mass within the liver.  Debris or septation are sometimes noted.
  • CT (ideally with intravenous contrast):  More sensitive than an ultrasound, a CT scan (
    image 1
    ) can provide detailed information about the abscess, including its size, location, and any complications.  Rim enhancement with surrounding edema are relatively specific but not often seen.
  • MRI can be used to differentiate abscesses from other liver lesions, such as tumors.

Differential diagnosis

Entamoeba histolytica abscess



Amebiasis manifestations include amebic dysentery (eg, subacute diarrhea) and extraintestinal manifestations, most commonly amebic liver abscess (a leading cause of death due to parasitic infection).  Both pyogenic liver abscesses and amebic liver abscesses can present with similar symptoms.  However, pyogenic abscesses are typically seen in patients who are ill-appearing, elderly, and have comorbidities (eg, diabetes mellitus).



In contrast, amebic liver abscesses tend to present in younger patients (men > women) who have an exposure history (typically within weeks but sometimes years), with a lower likelihood of hyperbilirubinemia and left shift on white cell count.  Serology is positive in most patients, and stool examination may reveal cysts or trophozoites of E histolytica (eg, in patients with concurrent diarrhea).  Drainage ("anchovy paste," proteinaceous debris from necrotic hepatocytes) is not usually necessary.  Treatment is with tissue agents (eg, metronidazole, tinidazole, nitazoxanide) followed by luminal agents (eg, paromomycin) to destroy intraluminal cysts.

Echinococcus cyst



Echinococcus (dog tapeworm in rural areas of resource-limited regions, with sheep as intermediate host and humans as incidental hosts) can cause cystic echinococcosis (E granulosus) with a hydatid liver cyst.  Patients are usually initially asymptomatic.  Large (>10 cm) cysts may cause right upper quadrant pain and hepatomegaly but fever is rare in the absence of cyst rupture, which typically causes a hypersensitivity reaction with fever.  Eosinophilia can occur, and serological tests for Echinococcus antibodies may be positive.



Ultrasonography may show a smooth, anechoic cyst, but internal septation (daughter cysts) and "hydatid sand" (hooklets and scolexes of protoscolices) are also classic features.  "Eggshell" calcification (

figure 1
) of a hepatic cyst on CT scan is highly suggestive of a hydatid cyst.  Small cysts (<5 cm) are typically treated with albendazole; larger or complex cysts usually also require percutaneous therapy or surgery, although risk of anaphylactic shock exists due to cyst content spillage.  Alveolar echinococcosis (E multilocularis) is more often symptomatic (right upper quadrant pain, weight loss, sometimes mimicking hepatocellular carcinoma), with imaging showing irregular lesions (poorly defined wall, irregular calcifications, necrosis).

Benign or malignant liver tumors



Primary or metastatic liver tumors can mimic pyogenic abscesses.  Hepatic hemangiomas are vascular tumors that can be difficult to differentiate from abscesses.  Imaging (eg, MRI with gadolinium contrast) can help distinguish these lesions.

Other



Cholecystitis, pancreatitis, and appendicitis can sometimes cause right-sided pain and fever, but imaging will distinguish them from abscesses.

Management



Management of pyogenic abscess includes blood cultures, intravenous antibiotics, and abscess drainage with culture of the aspirated material.

Antibiotics



Broad-spectrum antibiotics are usually initiated empirically and tailored to the organisms recovered on blood culture.  Common antibiotic regimens for pyogenic liver abscesses include:



  • Metronidazole (anaerobic and E histolytica coverage) with a third (or higher) generation cephalosporin
  • Combination beta-lactam and beta-lactam inhibitor (with or without metronidazole for empiric E histolytica coverage)
  • Fluoroquinolone with metronidazole


Vancomycin can be added to ensure S aureus coverage in patients with septic shock or recent indwelling catheter or injection drug use.



Several weeks of antibiotics are recommended.

Drainage



Abscesses may require drainage to promote healing and prevent complications.  Drainage can be performed surgically or percutaneously under ultrasound or CT guidance.  Percutaneous drainage is typically preferred, as it is less invasive and carries a lower risk of complications.



  • For small (â‰¤5 cm) single, unilocular abscesses, needle aspiration alone or with drainage catheter placement can be considered.
  • For larger single, unilocular abscesses, drainage catheters are preferred.


Surgical drainage may be necessary in some cases, such as when the abscess is very large, complex, or associated with other complications.



Aspirate should be sent for Gram stain and culture.  In addition, a sample should be saved for additional testing (eg, PCR testing for E histolytica, parasite stains) in case bacterial cultures are not revealing.

Complications



Complications of pyogenic liver abscesses include:



  • Rupture:  Abscesses can rupture into the peritoneal cavity, leading to peritonitis.
  • Sepsis:  Severe infections can lead to sepsis, a life-threatening condition.
  • Liver abscess extension:  Abscesses can extend into adjacent structures, such as the gallbladder or pancreas.  Occasionally, abscess rupture and pleural space seeding creates an empyema.
  • Hemorrhage:  Abscesses can involve blood vessels, leading to bleeding.
  • Other complications can include liver failure, renal failure, and respiratory failure.


Pyogenic liver abscesses are associated with colorectal cancer, so screening colonoscopy is recommended.

Summary



Pyogenic liver abscesses are collections of pus within the liver caused by bacterial infections.  They can result from direct spread from the biliary tract or hematogenous spread through the portal vein or systemic circulation.  Common pathogens include enteric gram-negative bacilli, streptococci, or Staphylococcus aureus.  Risk factors include diabetes, immunosuppression, hepatobiliary or pancreatic disease, foreign bodies, or chronic granulomatous disease.  Pyogenic liver abscesses typically present with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and hepatomegaly.  Leukocytosis, elevated liver enzymes, and inflammatory markers may be present.  Diagnosis is made with imaging studies such as ultrasonography and CT.  Management includes antibiotics and drainage of the abscess.
